title: How will I know if my bank account will be garnished?
question: I generated debt while in Colorado and the judgement was found to be against me. Shortly thereafter I moved to Nevada and opened a new bank account in a local bank there. Before I moved I received a notice that my wages would be garnished but I moved again to California and no longer work at the job they were going to garnish my wages from. I still owe about $3600. Can my bank account be garnished now? How can they do that if the judgement was in Colorado but the bank is in Nevada?
question_tags: Business contracts,Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Lawsuits and disputes
answers:
A judgment from one state can be domesticated in any other state. There are even international treaties that allow it to be enforced in other countries.

Be sure that the company does not try to evade the laws that protect you from illegal collection attempts from non-domesticated judgments. I have seen debt collection agencies attempt to enforce an out-of-state judgment on someone living in another state, by taking advantage of the fact that the employer or the bank had offices in the state where the judgment was filed, but the employee/account holder lived in another state. That is most likely illegal and you should be sure to consult with an attorney who has experience in defending debt collection lawsuits, as this would probably be an abuse of the legal process.

One thing to do is what you did when you lived in Nevada: have a bank account in a small local bank, not a big bank with branches all over. It may even be to your advantage to open your account in a state where you don't live and then do internet banking and bank by mail. Hopefully, your current employer is not in several states, because I have seen where these employers don't do enough to fight improper attempts to collect a money judgment from an employee.

One other tip is no bank account and keep the cash well hidden at home (not in the freezer). Better still, hold the funds in postal money orders made payable to you or to whomever you expect to pay for something, such as the landlord's rent money, so you don't have too much cash.

Robert Stempler
www.StopCollectionLawsuits.com

To levy assets in a different state from where the judgment was entered, the judgment creditor must domesticate the judgment in the state where the assets are located. As such, once the Colorado judgment is domesticated in Nevada, the creditor can levy the Nevada bank account. I strongly advise contacting the creditor and making arrangements to avoid future levy problems.

The creditor has to take the judgment to the state where your bank account is located & register it. You should be sent notice of the registration, if the creditor is able to find you. If not, "substituted service" may be used & this process almost never provides you with actual notice. (Still, you have no one to blame but yourself if you move without leaving a forwarding address.)

Registration of a judgment from another state isn't a very complicated process and the amount of time you have to respond to the registration is fairly short. Any defenses to the registration are extremely limited.

Once the registration processs is completed, the new state rubber stamps the order from the old state and the creditor can walk into the bank & seize your bank account. Of course, if your current account is with a bank that has even one branch in your old state, the creditor may be able to seize the account contents without bothering to register the judgment.

Hope this perspective helps!
The judgment creditor will have to domesticate the Colorado judgment in the state in which he/she/it intends to garnish your income or assets.
